The functions treated in this chapter are the solutions of the Painlevé equations \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}} – \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}}.

The six Painlevé equations \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}} – \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} are as follows: \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}=6w^{2}+z, \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}=2w^{3}+zw+\alpha, \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}=\frac{1}{w}\left(\frac{\mathrm{d}w }{\mathrm{d}z}\right)^{2}-\frac{1}{z}\frac{\mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d}z}+\frac{ \alpha w^{2}+\beta}{z}+\gamma w^{3}+\frac{\delta}{w},
with \alpha , \beta , \gamma , and \delta arbitrary constants.
The solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}} – \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} are called the Painlevé transcendents.
The six equations are sometimes referred to as the Painlevé transcendents, but in this chapter this term will be used only for their solutions.

Let \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}=F\left(z,w,\frac{\mathrm{d}w}{ \mathrm{d}z}\right), be a nonlinear second-order differential equation in which F is a rational function of w and \ifrac{\mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d}z} , and is locally analytic in z , that is, analytic except for isolated singularities in \mathbb{C}.
In general the singularities of the solutions are movable in the sense that their location depends on the constants of integration associated with the initial orboundary conditions.

An equation is said to have the Painlevé property if all its solutions are free from movable branch points; the solutions may have movable poles or movable isolated essential singularities (§LABEL:sec:AL.FC.ls), however.
There are fifty equations with the Painlevé property.
They are distinct modulo Möbius (bilinear) transformations W(\zeta)=\frac{a(z)w+b(z)}{c(z)w+d(z)}, \zeta=\phi(z), in which a(z) , b(z) , c(z) , d(z) , and \phi(z) are locally analytic functions.

The fifty equations can be reduced to linear equations, solved in terms of elliptic functions (Chapters LABEL:ch:JA and LABEL:ch:WE), or reduced to one of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}} – \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}}.

For arbitrary values of the parameters \alpha , \beta , \gamma , and \delta , the general solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}} – \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} are transcendental, that is, they cannot be expressed in closed-form elementary functions.

However, for special values of the parameters, equations \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} – \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} have special solutions in terms of elementary functions, or special functions defined elsewhere in the DLMF.
If \gamma\delta\neq 0 in \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} , then set \gamma=1 and \delta=-1 , without loss of generality, by rescaling w and z if necessary.
If \gamma=0 and \alpha\delta\neq 0 in \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} , then set \alpha=1 and \delta=-1 , without loss of generality.
Lastly, if \delta=0 and \beta\gamma\neq 0 , then set \beta=-1 and \gamma=1 , without loss ofgenerality.
If \delta\neq 0 in \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} , then set \delta=-\tfrac{1}{2} , without loss of generality.

In \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} , if w(z)=\zeta^{-1/2}u(\zeta) with \zeta=z^{2} , then \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}u}{{\mathrm{d}\zeta}^{2}}=\frac{1}{u}\left(\frac{\mathrm {d}u}{\mathrm{d}\zeta}\right)^{2}-\frac{1}{\zeta}\frac{\mathrm{d}u}{\mathrm{d} \zeta}+\frac{u^{2}(\alpha+\gamma u)}{4\zeta^{2}}+\frac{\beta}{4\zeta}+\frac{ \delta}{4u}, which is known as \mbox{P}^{\prime}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}}.

In \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} , if w(z)=\exp\left(-iu(z)\right) , \beta=-\alpha , and \delta=-\gamma , then \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}u}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}+\frac{1}{z}\frac{\mathrm{d}u}{ \mathrm{d}z}=\frac{2\alpha}{z}\sin u+2\gamma\sin\left(2u\right).

In \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize IV}} , if w(z)=2\sqrt{2}(u(\zeta))^{2} with \zeta=\sqrt{2}z and \alpha=2\nu+1 , then \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}u}{{\mathrm{d}\zeta}^{2}}=3u^{5}+2\zeta u^{3}+\left( \tfrac{1}{4}\zeta^{2}-\nu-\tfrac{1}{2}\right)u+\frac{\beta}{32u^{3}}.
When \beta=0 this is a nonlinear harmonic oscillator.

In \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} , if w(z)=(\coth u(\zeta))^{2} with \zeta=\ln z , then \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}u}{{\mathrm{d}\zeta}^{2}}=-\frac{\alpha\cosh u}{2(\sinh u )^{3}}-\frac{\beta\sinh u}{2(\cosh u)^{3}}-\tfrac{1}{4}\gamma e^{\zeta}\sinh \left(2u\right)-\tfrac{1}{8}\delta e^{2\zeta}\sinh\left(4u\right).
See also ( ) , ( ) , ( ) , ( ) , and ( ) .

\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} can be written in the form z(1-z)I\left(\int_{\infty}^{w}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{t(t-1)(t-z)}}\right)= \sqrt{w(w-1)(w-z)}\*\left(\alpha+\frac{\beta z}{w^{2}}+\frac{\gamma(z-1)}{(w-1 )^{2}}+(\delta-\tfrac{1}{2})\frac{z(z-1)}{(w-z)^{2}}\right), where I=z(1-z)\frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}+(1-2z)\frac{\mathrm{d}}{ \mathrm{d}z}-\frac{1}{4}.

Let \frac{\mathrm{d}f_{1}}{\mathrm{d}z}+f_{1}(f_{2}-f_{3})+2\mu_{1}=0, \frac{\mathrm{d}f_{2}}{\mathrm{d}z}+f_{2}(f_{3}-f_{1})+2\mu_{2}=0, \frac{\mathrm{d}f_{3}}{\mathrm{d}z}+f_{3}(f_{1}-f_{2})+2\mu_{3}=0, where \mu_{1} , \mu_{2} , \mu_{3} are constants, f_{1} , f_{2} , f_{3} are functions of z , with \mu_{1}+\mu_{2}+\mu_{3}=1, f_{1}(z)+f_{2}(z)+f_{3}(z)+2z=0.
Then w(z)=f_{1}(z) satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize IV}} with (\alpha,\beta)=(\mu_{3}-\mu_{2},-2\mu_{1}^{2}).
See ( ) .
Then w(z)=1-(\sqrt{z}/f_{1}(z)) satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} with (\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta)=(\tfrac{1}{2}\mu_{1}^{2},-\tfrac{1}{2}\mu_{3}^{2} ,\mu_{4}-\mu_{2},-\tfrac{1}{2}).

\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}} – \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} are obtained from \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} by a coalescence cascade: \begin{array}[]{ccccccc}\mbox{$\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}}$}& \longrightarrow&\mbox{$\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}}$}&\longrightarrow&\mbox {$\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize IV}}$}\\ &&\big{\downarrow}&&\big{\downarrow}\\ &&\mbox{$\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}}$}&\longrightarrow&\mbox{$\mbox{P}_{ \mbox{\scriptsize II}}$}&\longrightarrow&\mbox{$\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I} }$}\end{array}

For example, if in \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} w(z;\alpha)=\epsilon W(\zeta)+\frac{1}{\epsilon^{5}}, z=\epsilon^{2}\zeta-\frac{6}{\epsilon^{10}}, \alpha=\frac{4}{\epsilon^{15}}, then \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}W}{{\mathrm{d}\zeta}^{2}}=6W^{2}+\zeta+\epsilon^{6}(2W^{ 3}+\zeta W); thus in the limit as \epsilon\to 0 , W(\zeta) satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}} with z=\zeta.

If in \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} w(z;\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta)=1+2\epsilon W(\zeta;a), z=1+\epsilon^{2}\zeta, \alpha=-\tfrac{1}{2}\epsilon^{-6}, \beta=\tfrac{1}{2}\epsilon^{-6}+2a\epsilon^{-3}, \gamma=-\delta=\tfrac{1}{4}\epsilon^{-6}, then as \epsilon\to 0 , W(\zeta;a) satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} with z=\zeta , \alpha=a.

If in \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize IV}} w(z;\alpha,\beta)=2^{2/3}\epsilon^{-1}W(\zeta;a)+\epsilon^{-3}, z=2^{-2/3}\epsilon\zeta-\epsilon^{-3}, \alpha=-2a-\tfrac{1}{2}\epsilon^{-6}, \beta=-\tfrac{1}{2}\epsilon^{-12}, then as \epsilon\to 0 , W(\zeta;a) satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} with z=\zeta , \alpha=a.

If in \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} w(z;\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta)=1+\epsilon\zeta W(\zeta;a,b,c,d), z=\zeta^{2}, \alpha=\tfrac{1}{4}a\epsilon^{-1}+\tfrac{1}{8}c\epsilon^{-2}, \beta=-\tfrac{1}{8}c\epsilon^{-2}, \gamma=\tfrac{1}{4}\epsilon b, \delta=\tfrac{1}{8}\epsilon^{2}d, then as \epsilon\to 0 , W(\zeta;a,b,c,d) satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} with z=\zeta , \alpha=a , \beta=b , \gamma=c , \delta=d.

If in \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} w(z;\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta)=\tfrac{1}{2}\sqrt{2}\epsilon W(\zeta;a,b), z=1+\sqrt{2}\epsilon\zeta, \alpha=\tfrac{1}{2}\epsilon^{-4}, \beta=\tfrac{1}{4}b, \gamma=-\epsilon^{-4}, \delta=a\epsilon^{-2}-\tfrac{1}{2}\epsilon^{-4}, then as \epsilon\to 0 , W(\zeta;a,b) satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize IV}} with z=\zeta , \alpha=a , \beta=b.

Lastly, if in \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} w(z;\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta)=W(\zeta;a,b,c,d), z=1+\epsilon\zeta, \gamma=c\epsilon^{-1}-d\epsilon^{-2}, \delta=d\epsilon^{-2}, then as \epsilon\to 0 , W(\zeta;a,b,c,d) satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} with z=\zeta , \alpha=a , \beta=b , \gamma=c , \delta=d.

para.sentence: \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}} – \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} can be expressed as the compatibility condition of a linear system, called an isomonodromy problem or Lax pair.

Suppose \frac{\partial\boldsymbol{{\Psi}}}{\partial\lambda}=\mathbf{A}(z,\lambda) \boldsymbol{{\Psi}}, \frac{\partial\boldsymbol{{\Psi}}}{\partial z}=\mathbf{B}(z,\lambda) \boldsymbol{{\Psi}}, is a linear system in which \mathbf{A} and \mathbf{B} are matrices and \lambda is independent of z.

Then the equation \frac{{\partial}^{2}\boldsymbol{{\Psi}}}{\partial z\partial\lambda}=\frac{{ \partial}^{2}\boldsymbol{{\Psi}}}{\partial\lambda\partial z}, is satisfied provided that \frac{\partial\mathbf{A}}{\partial z}-\frac{\partial\mathbf{B}}{\partial \lambda}+\mathbf{A}\mathbf{B}-\mathbf{B}\mathbf{A}=0.
(LABEL:eq:PT.IP.comcond) is the compatibility condition of (LABEL:eq:PT.IP.gen).
Isomonodromy problems for Painlevé equations are not unique.

\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}} is the compatibility condition of (LABEL:eq:PT.IP.gen) with \mathbf{A}(z,\lambda)=(4\lambda^{4}+2w^{2}+z)\begin{bmatrix}1&0\\ 0&-1\end{bmatrix}-i(4\lambda^{2}w+2w^{2}+z)\begin{bmatrix}0&-i\\ i&0\end{bmatrix}-\left(2\lambda w^{\prime}+\frac{1}{2\lambda}\right)\begin{ bmatrix}0&1\\ 1&0\end{bmatrix}, \mathbf{B}(z,\lambda)=\left(\lambda+\dfrac{w}{\lambda}\right)\begin{bmatrix}1& 0\\ 0&-1\end{bmatrix}-\dfrac{iw}{\lambda}\begin{bmatrix}0&-i\\ i&0\end{bmatrix}.

\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} is the compatibility condition of (LABEL:eq:PT.IP.gen) with \mathbf{A}(z,\lambda)=-i(4\lambda^{2}+2w^{2}+z)\begin{bmatrix}1&0\\ 0&-1\end{bmatrix}-2w^{\prime}\begin{bmatrix}0&-i\\ i&0\end{bmatrix}+\left(4\lambda w-\frac{\alpha}{\lambda}\right)\begin{bmatrix} 0&1\\ 1&0\end{bmatrix}, \mathbf{B}(z,\lambda)=\begin{bmatrix}-i\lambda&w\\ w&i\lambda\end{bmatrix}.
See ( ) .

The compatibility condition of (LABEL:eq:PT.IP.gen) with \mathbf{A}(z,\lambda)=\begin{bmatrix}\tfrac{1}{4}z&0\\ 0&-\tfrac{1}{4}z\end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix}-\tfrac{1}{2}\theta_{\infty}&u_{0 }\\ u_{1}&\tfrac{1}{2}\theta_{\infty}\end{bmatrix}\dfrac{1}{\lambda}+\begin{ bmatrix}v_{0}-\tfrac{1}{4}z&-v_{1}v_{0}\\ \ifrac{(v_{0}-\tfrac{1}{2}z)}{v_{1}}&\tfrac{1}{4}z-v_{0}\end{bmatrix}\frac{1}{ \lambda^{2}}, \mathbf{B}(z,\lambda)=\begin{bmatrix}\tfrac{1}{4}&0\\ 0&-\tfrac{1}{4}\end{bmatrix}\lambda+\begin{bmatrix}0&u_{0}\\ u_{1}&0\end{bmatrix}\dfrac{1}{z}-\begin{bmatrix}v_{0}-\tfrac{1}{4}z&-v_{1}v_{0 }\\ \ifrac{(v_{0}-\tfrac{1}{2}z)}{v_{1}}&\tfrac{1}{4}z-v_{0}\end{bmatrix}\frac{1}{ z\lambda}, where \theta_{\infty} is an arbitrary constant, is zu_{0}^{\prime}=\theta_{\infty}u_{0}-zv_{0}v_{1}, zu_{1}^{\prime}=-\theta_{\infty}u_{1}-(\ifrac{z(2v_{0}-z)}{(2v_{1})}), zv_{0}^{\prime}=2v_{0}u_{1}v_{1}+v_{0}+(u_{0}(2v_{0}-z)/v_{1}), zv_{1}^{\prime}=2u_{0}-2u_{1}v_{1}^{2}-\theta_{\infty}v_{1}.

If w=-u_{0}/(v_{0}v_{1}) , then zw^{\prime}=(4v_{0}-z)w^{2}+(2\theta_{\infty}-1)w+z, and w satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} with (\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta)=\left(2\theta_{0},2(1-\theta_{\infty}),1,-1\right), where \theta_{0}=\frac{4v_{0}}{z}\left(\theta_{\infty}\left(1-\frac{z}{4v_{0}}\right )+\frac{z-2v_{0}}{2v_{0}v_{1}}u_{0}+u_{1}v_{1}\right).
Note that the right-hand side of the last equation is a first integral of the system (LABEL:eq:PT.IP.MIIIc1)–(LABEL:eq:PT.IP.MIIIc4).
For isomonodromy problems for \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize IV}} , \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} , and \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} see ( ) .

Let K(z,\zeta) be the solution of K(z,\zeta)=k\mathrm{Ai}\left(\frac{z+\zeta}{2}\right)+\frac{k^{2}}{4}\*\int_{z }^{\infty}\!\!\!\int_{z}^{\infty}K(z,s)\mathrm{Ai}\left(\frac{s+t}{2}\right) \mathrm{Ai}\left(\frac{t+\zeta}{2}\right)\mathrm{d}s\mathrm{d}t, where k is a real constant, and \mathrm{Ai}\left(z\right) is defined in §LABEL:sec:AI.DE. Then w(z)=K(z,z), satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} with \alpha=0 and the boundary condition w(z)\sim k\mathrm{Ai}\left(z\right), subject to z\to+\infty.

\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}} – \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} can be written as a Hamiltonian system \frac{\mathrm{d}q}{\mathrm{d}z}=\frac{\partial\mathrm{H}}{\partial p}, \frac{\mathrm{d}p}{\mathrm{d}z}=-\frac{\partial\mathrm{H}}{\partial q}, for suitable (non-autonomous) Hamiltonian functions \mathrm{H}(q,p,z).
The Hamiltonian for \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}} is \mathrm{H}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}}(q,p,z)=\tfrac{1}{2}p^{2}-2q^{3}-zq, and so q^{\prime}=p, p^{\prime}=6q^{2}+z.
Then q=w satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}}.

The function \sigma=\mathrm{H}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}}(q,p,z), defined by (LABEL:eq:PT.HM.DE11) satisfies \left(\sigma^{\prime\prime}\right)^{2}+4\left(\sigma^{\prime}\right)^{3}+2z \sigma^{\prime}-2\sigma=0.
Conversely, if \sigma is a solution of (LABEL:eq:PT.HM.DE14), then q=-\sigma^{\prime}, p=-\sigma^{\prime\prime}, are solutions of (LABEL:eq:PT.HM.DE12) and (LABEL:eq:PT.HM.DE13).

The Hamiltonian for \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} is \mathrm{H}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}}(q,p,z)=\tfrac{1}{2}p^{2}-(q^{2}+\tfrac{1}{2 }z)p-(\alpha+\tfrac{1}{2})q, and so q^{\prime}=p-q^{2}-\tfrac{1}{2}z, p^{\prime}=2qp+\alpha+\tfrac{1}{2}.
Then q=w satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} and p satisfies pp^{\prime\prime}=\tfrac{1}{2}(p^{\prime})^{2}+2p^{3}-zp^{2}-\tfrac{1}{2}( \alpha+\tfrac{1}{2})^{2}.

The function \sigma(z)=\mathrm{H}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}}(q,p,z) defined by ( LABEL:eq:PT.HM.DE21) satisfies \left(\sigma^{\prime\prime}\right)^{2}+4\left(\sigma^{\prime}\right)^{3}+2 \sigma^{\prime}\left(z\sigma^{\prime}-\sigma\right)=\tfrac{1}{4}(\alpha+\tfrac {1}{2})^{2}.

Conversely, if \sigma(z) is a solution of (LABEL:eq:PT.HM.DE25), then q=\ifrac{(4\sigma^{\prime\prime}+2\alpha+1)}{(8\sigma^{\prime})}, p=-2\sigma^{\prime}, are solutions of (LABEL:eq:PT.HM.DE22) and (LABEL:eq:PT.HM.DE23).

The Hamiltonian for \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} is z\mathrm{H}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}}(q,p,z)=q^{2}p^{2}-{\left(\kappa_{\infty} zq^{2}+(2\theta_{0}+1)q-\kappa_{0}z\right)p}+\kappa_{\infty}(\theta_{0}+\theta _{\infty})zq, and so zq^{\prime}=2q^{2}p-\kappa_{\infty}zq^{2}-(2\theta_{0}+1)q+\kappa_{0}z, , zp^{\prime}=-2qp^{2}+2\kappa_{\infty}zqp+(2\theta_{0}+1)p-\kappa_{\infty}( \theta_{0}+\theta_{\infty})z.
Then q=w satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} with (\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta)=\left(-2\kappa_{\infty}\theta_{\infty},2\kappa_{0 }(\theta_{0}+1),\kappa_{\infty}^{2},-\kappa_{0}^{2}\right).

The function \sigma=z\mathrm{H}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}}(q,p,z)+pq+\theta_{0}^{2}-\tfrac{1} {2}\kappa_{0}\kappa_{\infty}z^{2} defined by (LABEL:eq:PT.HM3.DE31) satisfies (z\sigma^{\prime\prime}-\sigma^{\prime})^{2}+2\left((\sigma^{\prime})^{2}- \kappa_{0}^{2}\kappa_{\infty}^{2}z^{2}\right)(z\sigma^{\prime}-2\sigma)+8 \kappa_{0}\kappa_{\infty}\theta_{0}\theta_{\infty}z\sigma^{\prime}=4\kappa_{0} ^{2}\kappa_{\infty}^{2}(\theta_{0}^{2}+\theta_{\infty}^{2})z^{2}.

Conversely, if \sigma is a solution of (LABEL:eq:PT.HM3.DE34), then q=\frac{\kappa_{0}\left(z\sigma^{\prime\prime}-(2\theta_{0}+1)\sigma^{\prime}+ 2\kappa_{0}\kappa_{\infty}\theta_{\infty}z\right)}{\kappa_{0}^{2}\kappa_{ \infty}^{2}z^{2}-(\sigma^{\prime})^{2}}, p=\ifrac{(\sigma^{\prime}+\kappa_{0}\kappa_{\infty}z)}{(2\kappa_{0})}, are solutions of (LABEL:eq:PT.HM3.DE32) and (LABEL:eq:PT.HM3.DE33).

The Hamiltonian for \mbox{P}^{\prime}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} (§LABEL:sec:PT.DE.APE) is \zeta\mathrm{H}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}}(q,p,\zeta)=q^{2}p^{2}-\left(\eta_{ \infty}q^{2}+\theta_{0}q-\eta_{0}\zeta\right)p+\tfrac{1}{2}\eta_{\infty}( \theta_{0}+\theta_{\infty})q, and so \zeta q^{\prime}=2q^{2}p-\eta_{\infty}q^{2}-\theta_{0}q+\eta_{0}\zeta, \zeta p^{\prime}=-2qp^{2}+2\eta_{\infty}qp+\theta_{0}p-\tfrac{1}{2}\eta_{ \infty}(\theta_{0}+\theta_{1}).
Then q=u satisfies \mbox{P}^{\prime}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} with (\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta)=\left(-4\eta_{\infty}\theta_{\infty},4\eta_{0}( \theta_{0}+1),4\eta_{\infty}^{2},-4\eta_{0}^{2}\right).

The function \sigma=\zeta\mathrm{H}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}}(q,p,\zeta)+\tfrac{1}{4}\theta_ {0}^{2}-\tfrac{1}{2}\eta_{0}\eta_{\infty}\zeta defined by (LABEL:eq:PT.HM3p.DE31) satisfies \zeta^{2}(\sigma^{\prime\prime})^{2}+\left(4(\sigma^{\prime})^{2}-\eta_{0}^{2} \eta_{\infty}^{2}\right)(\zeta\sigma^{\prime}-\sigma)+\eta_{0}\eta_{\infty} \theta_{0}\theta_{\infty}\sigma^{\prime}=\tfrac{1}{4}\eta_{0}^{2}\eta_{\infty} ^{2}(\theta_{0}^{2}+\theta_{\infty}^{2}).

Conversely, if \sigma is a solution of (LABEL:eq:PT.HM3p.DE34), then q=\frac{\eta_{0}\left(\zeta\sigma^{\prime\prime}-2\theta_{0}\sigma^{\prime}+ \eta_{0}\eta_{\infty}\theta_{\infty}\right)}{\eta_{0}^{2}\eta_{\infty}^{2}-4( \sigma^{\prime})^{2}}, p=\ifrac{(2\sigma^{\prime}+\eta_{0}\eta_{\infty}\zeta)}{(2\eta_{0})}, are solutions of (LABEL:eq:PT.HM3p.DE32) and (LABEL:eq:PT.HM3p.DE33).

The Hamiltonian for \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} with \gamma=0 is z\mathrm{H}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}}(q,p,z)=q^{2}p^{2}+(\theta q-\kappa_{0}z)p -\kappa_{\infty}zq, and so zq^{\prime}=2q^{2}p+\theta q-\kappa_{0}z, zp^{\prime}=-2qp^{2}-\theta p+\kappa_{\infty}z.
Then q=w satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} with (\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta)=\left(2\kappa_{\infty},\kappa_{0}(\theta-1),0,- \kappa_{0}^{2}\right).

The function \sigma=z\mathrm{H}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}}(q,p,z)+pq+\tfrac{1}{4}(\theta+1)^{2} defined by (LABEL:eq:PT.HM30.DE31) satisfies (z\sigma^{\prime\prime}-\sigma^{\prime})^{2}+2(\sigma^{\prime})^{2}(z\sigma^{ \prime}-2\sigma)-4\kappa_{0}\kappa_{\infty}(\theta+1)\theta_{\infty}z\sigma^{ \prime}=4\kappa_{0}^{2}\kappa_{\infty}^{2}z^{2}.

Conversely, if \sigma is a solution of (LABEL:eq:PT.HM30.DE34), then q=\ifrac{\kappa_{0}\left(z\sigma^{\prime\prime}-\theta\sigma^{\prime}+2\kappa_ {0}\kappa_{\infty}z\right)}{(\sigma^{\prime})^{2}}, p=\ifrac{\sigma^{\prime}}{(2\kappa_{0})}, are solutions of (LABEL:eq:PT.HM30.DE32) and (LABEL:eq:PT.HM30.DE33).
For Hamiltonian structure for \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize IV}} see ( ) , ( ) ; also ( ) .
For Hamiltonian structure for \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} see ( ) , ( ) ; also ( ) .
For Hamiltonian structure for \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} see ( ) and ( ) ; also ( ) .

With the exception of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}} , a Bäcklund transformation relates a Painlevé transcendent of one type either to another of the same type but with different values of the parameters, or to another type.
Let w=w(z;\alpha) be a solution of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}}.

Then the transformations \mathcal{S}:\enskip w(z;-\alpha)=-w, and \mathcal{T}^{\pm}:\enskip w(z;\alpha\pm 1)=-w-\frac{2\alpha\pm 1}{2w^{2}\pm 2w ^{\prime}+z}, furnish solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} , provided that \alpha\neq\mp\tfrac{1}{2}.

\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} also has the special transformation W(\zeta;\tfrac{1}{2}\varepsilon)=\frac{2^{-1/3}\varepsilon}{w(z;0)}\frac{ \mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}w(z;0), or equivalently, w^{2}(z;0)=2^{-1/3}\left(W^{2}(\zeta;\tfrac{1}{2}\varepsilon)-\varepsilon\frac {\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}\zeta}W(\zeta;\tfrac{1}{2}\varepsilon)+\tfrac{1}{2} \zeta\right), with \zeta=-2^{1/3}z and \varepsilon=\pm 1 , where W(\zeta;\tfrac{1}{2}\varepsilon) satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} with z=\zeta , \alpha=\tfrac{1}{2}\varepsilon , and w(z;0) satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} with \alpha=0.

The solutions w_{\alpha}=w(z;\alpha) , w_{\alpha\pm 1}=w(z;\alpha\pm 1) , satisfy the nonlinear recurrence relation \frac{\alpha+\tfrac{1}{2}}{w_{\alpha+1}+w_{\alpha}}+\frac{\alpha-\tfrac{1}{2}} {w_{\alpha}+w_{\alpha-1}}+2w_{\alpha}^{2}+z=0.
See ( ) .

Let w_{j}=w(z;\alpha_{j},\beta_{j},\gamma_{j},\delta_{j}) , j=0,1,2 , be solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} with (\alpha_{1},\beta_{1},\gamma_{1},\delta_{1})=(-\alpha_{0},-\beta_{0},\gamma_{0 },\delta_{0}), (\alpha_{2},\beta_{2},\gamma_{2},\delta_{2})=(-\beta_{0},-\alpha_{0},-\delta_{ 0},-\gamma_{0}).
Then \mathcal{S}_{1}:\enskip w_{1}=-w_{0}, , \mathcal{S}_{2}:\enskip w_{2}=\ifrac{1}{w_{0}}.

Next, let W_{j}=W(z;\alpha_{j},\beta_{j},1,-1) , j=0,1,2,3,4 , be solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} with \alpha_{1}=\alpha_{3}=\alpha_{0}+2, \alpha_{2}=\alpha_{4}=\alpha_{0}-2, \beta_{1}=\beta_{2}=\beta_{0}+2, \beta_{3}=\beta_{4}=\beta_{0}-2.
See ( ) .
If \gamma=0 and \alpha\delta\neq 0 , then set \alpha=1 and \delta=-1 , without loss of generality.
Let u_{j}=w(z;1,\beta_{j},0,-1) , j=0,5,6 , be solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} with \beta_{5}=\beta_{0}+2, \beta_{6}=\beta_{0}-2.
Then \mathcal{T}_{5}:\enskip u_{5}=\ifrac{(zu_{0}^{\prime}+z-(\beta_{0}+1)u_{0})}{u _{0}^{2}}, , \mathcal{T}_{6}:\enskip u_{6}=-\ifrac{(zu_{0}^{\prime}-z+(\beta_{0}-1)u_{0})}{ u_{0}^{2}}.
Similar results hold for \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} with \delta=0 and \beta\gamma\neq 0.
Furthermore, w(z;a,b,0,0)=W^{2}(\zeta;0,0,a,b), z=\tfrac{1}{2}\zeta^{2}.

Let w_{0}=w(z;\alpha_{0},\beta_{0}) and w_{j}^{\pm}=w(z;\alpha_{j}^{\pm},\beta_{j}^{\pm}) , j=1,2,3,4 , be solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize IV}} with \alpha_{1}^{\pm}=\tfrac{1}{4}\left(2-2\alpha_{0}\pm 3\sqrt{-2\beta_{0}}\right), \beta_{1}^{\pm}=-\tfrac{1}{2}\left(1+\alpha_{0}\pm\tfrac{1}{2}\sqrt{-2\beta_{0 }}\right)^{2}, \alpha_{2}^{\pm}=-\tfrac{1}{4}\left(2+2\alpha_{0}\pm 3\sqrt{-2\beta_{0}}\right), \beta_{2}^{\pm}=-\tfrac{1}{2}\left(1-\alpha_{0}\pm\tfrac{1}{2}\sqrt{-2\beta_{0 }}\right)^{2}, \alpha_{3}^{\pm}=\tfrac{3}{2}-\tfrac{1}{2}\alpha_{0}\mp\tfrac{3}{4}\sqrt{-2 \beta_{0}}, \beta_{3}^{\pm}=-\tfrac{1}{2}\left(1-\alpha_{0}\pm\tfrac{1}{2}\sqrt{-2\beta_{0 }}\right)^{2}, \alpha_{4}^{\pm}=-\tfrac{3}{2}-\tfrac{1}{2}\alpha_{0}\mp\tfrac{3}{4}\sqrt{-2 \beta_{0}}, \beta_{4}^{\pm}=-\tfrac{1}{2}\left(-1-\alpha_{0}\pm\tfrac{1}{2}\sqrt{-2\beta_{ 0}}\right)^{2}.

Then \mathcal{T}_{1}^{\pm}:\enskip w_{1}^{\pm}=\frac{w_{0}^{\prime}-w_{0}^{2}-2zw_{ 0}\mp\sqrt{-2\beta_{0}}}{2w_{0}}, , \mathcal{T}_{2}^{\pm}:\enskip w_{2}^{\pm}=-\frac{w_{0}^{\prime}+w_{0}^{2}+2zw_ {0}\mp\sqrt{-2\beta_{0}}}{2w_{0}}, , \mathcal{T}_{3}^{\pm}:\enskip w_{3}^{\pm}=w_{0}+\frac{2\left(1-\alpha_{0}\mp \tfrac{1}{2}\sqrt{-2\beta_{0}}\right)w_{0}}{w_{0}^{\prime}\pm\sqrt{-2\beta_{0} }+2zw_{0}+w_{0}^{2}}, , \mathcal{T}_{4}^{\pm}:\enskip w_{4}^{\pm}=w_{0}+\frac{2\left(1+\alpha_{0}\pm \tfrac{1}{2}\sqrt{-2\beta_{0}}\right)w_{0}}{w_{0}^{\prime}\mp\sqrt{-2\beta_{0} }-2zw_{0}-w_{0}^{2}}, valid when the denominators are nonzero, and where the upper signs or the lower signs are taken throughout each transformation.
See ( ) .

Let w_{j}(z_{j})=w(z_{j};\alpha_{j},\beta_{j},\gamma_{j},\delta_{j}) , j=0,1,2 , besolutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} with z_{1}=-z_{0}, z_{2}=z_{0}, (\alpha_{1},\beta_{1},\gamma_{1},\delta_{1})=(\alpha_{0},\beta_{0},-\gamma_{0} ,\delta_{0}), (\alpha_{2},\beta_{2},\gamma_{2},\delta_{2})=(-\beta_{0},-\alpha_{0},-\gamma_{ 0},\delta_{0}).
Then \mathcal{S}_{1}:\enskip w_{1}(z_{1})=w(z_{0}), , \mathcal{S}_{2}:\enskip w_{2}(z_{2})=\ifrac{1}{w(z_{0})}.

Let W_{0}=W(z;\alpha_{0},\beta_{0},\gamma_{0},-\tfrac{1}{2}) and W_{1}=W(z;\alpha_{1},\beta_{1},\gamma_{1},-\tfrac{1}{2}) be solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} , where \alpha_{1}=\tfrac{1}{8}\left(\gamma_{0}+\varepsilon_{1}\left(1-\varepsilon_{3} \sqrt{-2\beta_{0}}-\varepsilon_{2}\sqrt{2\alpha_{0}}\right)\right)^{2}, \beta_{1}=-\tfrac{1}{8}\left(\gamma_{0}-\varepsilon_{1}\left(1-\varepsilon_{3} \sqrt{-2\beta_{0}}-\varepsilon_{2}\sqrt{2\alpha_{0}}\right)\right)^{2}, \gamma_{1}=\varepsilon_{1}\left(\varepsilon_{3}\sqrt{-2\beta_{0}}-\varepsilon_ {2}\sqrt{2\alpha_{0}}\right), and \varepsilon_{j}=\pm 1 , j=1,2,3 , independently.

Also let \Phi=zW_{0}^{\prime}-\varepsilon_{2}\sqrt{2\alpha_{0}}W_{0}^{2}+\varepsilon_{3 }\sqrt{-2\beta_{0}}+\left(\varepsilon_{2}\sqrt{2\alpha_{0}}-\varepsilon_{3} \sqrt{-2\beta_{0}}+\varepsilon_{1}z\right)W_{0}, and assume \Phi\neq 0.
Then \mathcal{T}_{\varepsilon_{1},\varepsilon_{2},\varepsilon_{3}}:\enskip W_{1}= \ifrac{(\Phi-2\varepsilon_{1}zW_{0})}{\Phi}, provided that the numerator on the right-hand side does not vanish.
Again, since \varepsilon_{j}=\pm 1 , j=1,2,3 , independently, there are eight distinct transformations of type \mathcal{T}_{\varepsilon_{1},\varepsilon_{2},\varepsilon_{3}}.

subsection.title: Relationship Between the Third and Fifth Painlevé Equations

para.sentence: Let w=w(z;\alpha,\beta,1,-1) be a solution of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} and v=w^{\prime}-\varepsilon w^{2}+(\ifrac{(1-\varepsilon\alpha)w}{z}), with \varepsilon=\pm 1.

Then W(\zeta;\alpha_{0},\beta_{0},\gamma_{0},\delta_{0})=\frac{v-1}{v+1}, z=\sqrt{2\zeta}, satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} with (\alpha_{0},\beta_{0},\gamma_{0},\delta_{0})={\left((\beta-\varepsilon\alpha+2 )^{2}/32,-(\beta+\varepsilon\alpha-2)^{2}/32,-\varepsilon,0\right)}.

Let w_{j}(z_{j})=w_{j}(z_{j};\alpha_{j},\beta_{j},\gamma_{j},\delta_{j}) , j=0,1,2,3 , be solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} with z_{1}=1/z_{0}, , z_{2}=1-z_{0}, , z_{3}=1/z_{0}, (\alpha_{1},\beta_{1},\gamma_{1},\delta_{1})=(\alpha_{0},\beta_{0},-\delta_{0} +\tfrac{1}{2},-\gamma_{0}+\tfrac{1}{2}), (\alpha_{2},\beta_{2},\gamma_{2},\delta_{2})=(\alpha_{0},-\gamma_{0},-\beta_{0 },\delta_{0}), (\alpha_{3},\beta_{3},\gamma_{3},\delta_{3})=(-\beta_{0},-\alpha_{0},\gamma_{0 },\delta_{0}).
The transformations \mathcal{S}_{j} , for j=1,2,3 , generate a group of order 24.

Let w(z;\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta) and W(z;A,B,C,D) be solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} with (\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta)=\left(\tfrac{1}{2}(\theta_{\infty}-1)^{2},-\tfrac {1}{2}\theta_{0}^{2},\tfrac{1}{2}\theta_{1}^{2},\tfrac{1}{2}(1-\theta_{2}^{2}) \right), (A,B,C,D)=\left(\tfrac{1}{2}(\Theta_{\infty}-1)^{2},-\tfrac{1}{2}\Theta_{0}^{2 },\tfrac{1}{2}\Theta_{1}^{2},\tfrac{1}{2}(1-\Theta_{2}^{2})\right), and \theta_{j}=\Theta_{j}+\tfrac{1}{2}\sigma, for j=0,1,2,\infty , where \sigma=\theta_{0}+\theta_{1}+\theta_{2}+\theta_{\infty}-1=1-(\Theta_{0}+\Theta _{1}+\Theta_{2}+\Theta_{\infty}).

Then \frac{\sigma}{w-W}=\frac{z(z-1)W^{\prime}}{W(W-1)(W-z)}+\frac{\Theta_{0}}{W}+ \frac{\Theta_{1}}{W-1}+\frac{\Theta_{2}-1}{W-z}=\frac{z(z-1)w^{\prime}}{w(w-1) (w-z)}+\frac{\theta_{0}}{w}+\frac{\theta_{1}}{w-1}+\frac{\theta_{2}-1}{w-z}.
\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} also has quadratic and quartic transformations.
Let w=w(z;\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta) be a solution of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}}.

The quadratic transformation u_{1}(\zeta_{1})=\frac{(1-w)(w-z)}{(1+\sqrt{z})^{2}w}, \zeta_{1}=\left(\frac{1-\sqrt{z}}{1+\sqrt{z}}\right)^{2}, transforms \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} with \alpha=-\beta and \gamma=\tfrac{1}{2}-\delta to \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} with (\alpha_{1},\beta_{1},\gamma_{1},\delta_{1})=(4\alpha,-4\gamma,0,\tfrac{1}{2}).

The quartic transformation u_{2}(\zeta_{2})=\frac{(w^{2}-z)^{2}}{4w(w-1)(w-z)}, \zeta_{2}=z, transforms \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} with \alpha=-\beta=\gamma=\tfrac{1}{2}-\delta to \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} with (\alpha_{2},\beta_{2},\gamma_{2},\delta_{2})=(16\alpha,0,0,\tfrac{1}{2}).

Also, u_{3}(\zeta_{3})=\left(\frac{1-z^{1/4}}{1+z^{1/4}}\right)^{2}\left(\frac{\sqrt {w}+z^{1/4}}{\sqrt{w}-z^{1/4}}\right)^{2}, \zeta_{3}=\left(\frac{1-z^{1/4}}{1+z^{1/4}}\right)^{4}, transforms \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} with \alpha=\beta=0 and \gamma=\tfrac{1}{2}-\delta to \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} with \alpha_{3}=\beta_{3} and \gamma_{3}=\tfrac{1}{2}-\delta_{3}.

\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} – \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} possess hierarchies of rational solutions for special values of the parameters which are generated from “seed solutions” using the Bäcklundtransformations and often can be expressed in the form of determinants.
See ( ) .

Rational solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} exist for \alpha=n(\in\mathbb{Z}) and are generated using the seed solution w(z;0)=0 and the Bäcklund transformations (LABEL:eq:PT.BT.P21) and (LABEL:eq:PT.BT.P22).

More generally, w(z;n)=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\left(\ln\left(\frac{Q_{n-1}(z)}{Q_{n}(z) }\right)\right), where the Q_{n}(z) are monic polynomials (coefficient of highest power of z is 1 ) satisfying Q_{n+1}(z)Q_{n-1}(z)={zQ_{n}^{2}(z)+4\left(Q_{n}^{\prime}(z)\right)^{2}-4Q_{n} (z)Q_{n}^{\prime\prime}(z)}, with Q_{0}(z)=1 , Q_{1}(z)=z.
Next, let p_{m}(z) be the polynomials defined by p_{m}(z)=0 for m<0 , and \sum_{m=0}^{\infty}p_{m}(z)\lambda^{m}=\exp\left(z\lambda-\tfrac{4}{3}\lambda^ {3}\right).

Then for n\geq 2 w(z;n)=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\left(\ln\left(\frac{\tau_{n-1}(z)}{\tau_ {n}(z)}\right)\right), where \tau_{n}(z) is the n\times n determinant \tau_{n}(z)=\begin{vmatrix}p_{1}(z)&p_{3}(z)&\cdots&p_{2n-1}(z)\\ p_{1}^{\prime}(z)&p_{3}^{\prime}(z)&\cdots&p_{2n-1}^{\prime}(z)\\ \vdots&\vdots&\ddots&\vdots\\ p_{1}^{(n-1)}(z)&p_{3}^{(n-1)}(z)&\cdots&p_{2n-1}^{(n-1)}(z)\end{vmatrix}.
For plots of the zeros of Q_{n}(z) see ( ) .

Special rational solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} are w(z;\mu,-\mu\kappa^{2},\lambda,-\lambda\kappa^{4})=\kappa, w(z;0,-\mu,0,\mu\kappa)=\kappa z, w(z;2\kappa+3,-2\kappa+1,1,-1)=\dfrac{z+\kappa}{z+\kappa+1}, with \kappa , \lambda , and \mu arbitrary constants.
In the general case assume \gamma\delta\neq 0 , so that as in§LABEL:sec:PT.DE.REN we may set \gamma=1 and \delta=-1.
Then \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} has rational solutions iff \alpha\pm\beta=4n, with n\in\mathbb{Z}.
These solutions have the form w(z)=\ifrac{P_{m}(z)}{Q_{m}(z)}, where P_{m}(z) and Q_{m}(z) are polynomials of degree m , with no common zeros.
For examples and plots see ( ) ; also ( ) .
For determinantal representations see ( ) .
Special rational solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize IV}} are w_{1}(z;\pm 2,-2)=\pm\ifrac{1}{z}, , w_{2}(z;0,-2)=-2z, , w_{3}(z;0,-\tfrac{2}{9})=-\tfrac{2}{3}z.

There are also three families of solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize IV}} of the form w_{1}(z;\alpha_{1},\beta_{1})=\ifrac{P_{1,n-1}(z)}{Q_{1,n}(z)}, w_{2}(z;\alpha_{2},\beta_{2})=-2z+(\ifrac{P_{2,n-1}(z)}{Q_{2,n}(z)}), w_{3}(z;\alpha_{3},\beta_{3})=-\tfrac{2}{3}z+(\ifrac{P_{3,n-1}(z)}{Q_{3,n}(z)}), where P_{j,n-1}(z) and Q_{j,n}(z) are polynomials of degrees n-1 and n , respectively, with no common zeros.
In general, \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize IV}} has rational solutions iff either \alpha=m, \beta=-2(1+2n-m)^{2}, or \mspace{12.0mu }\alpha=m, \beta=-2(\tfrac{1}{3}+2n-m)^{2}, with m,n\in\mathbb{Z}.
The rational solutions when the parameters satisfy (LABEL:eq:PT.RS.P44a) are special cases of §LABEL:sec:PT.SF.P4.
For examples and plots see ( ) ; also ( ) .
For determinantal representations see ( ) and ( ) .

Special rational solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} are w(z;\tfrac{1}{2},-\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2},\kappa(2-\mu),-\tfrac{1}{2}\kappa^{2})= \kappa z+\mu, w(z;\tfrac{1}{2},\kappa^{2}\mu,2\kappa\mu,\mu)=\kappa/(z+\kappa), w(z;\tfrac{1}{8},-\tfrac{1}{8},-\kappa\mu,\mu)=(\kappa+z)/(\kappa-z), with \kappa and \mu arbitrary constants.
In the general case assume \delta\neq 0 , so that as in §LABEL:sec:PT.DE.REN we may set \delta=-\tfrac{1}{2}.

Then \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} has a rational solution iff one of the following holds with m,n\in\mathbb{Z} and \varepsilon=\pm 1 : \alpha=\tfrac{1}{2}(m+\varepsilon\gamma)^{2} and \beta=-\tfrac{1}{2}n^{2} , where n>0 , m+n is odd, and \alpha\neq 0 when |m|<n.
\alpha=\tfrac{1}{2}n^{2} and \beta=-\tfrac{1}{2}(m+\varepsilon\gamma)^{2} , where n>0 , m+n is odd, and \beta\neq 0 when |m|<n.
\alpha=\tfrac{1}{2}a^{2} , \beta=-\tfrac{1}{2}(a+n)^{2} , and \gamma=m , with m+n even.
\alpha=\tfrac{1}{2}(b+n)^{2} , \beta=-\tfrac{1}{2}b^{2} , and \gamma=m , with m+n even.
\alpha=\tfrac{1}{8}(2m+1)^{2} , \beta=-\tfrac{1}{8}(2n+1)^{2} , and \gamma\notin\mathbb{Z}.

These rational solutions have the form w(z)=\lambda z+\mu+(\ifrac{P_{n-1}(z)}{Q_{n}(z)}), where \lambda , \mu are constants, and P_{n-1}(z) , Q_{n}(z) are polynomials of degrees n-1 and n , respectively, with no common zeros.
Cases (a) and (b) are special cases of §LABEL:sec:PT.SF.P5.
For examples and plots see ( ) .
For determinantal representations see ( ) .
For the case \delta=0 see ( ) and ( ) .

Special rational solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} are w(z;\mu,-\mu\kappa^{2},\tfrac{1}{2},\tfrac{1}{2}-\mu(\kappa-1)^{2})=\kappa z, w(z;0,0,2,0)=\kappa z^{2}, , w(z;0,0,\tfrac{1}{2},-\tfrac{3}{2})=\ifrac{\kappa}{z}, , w(z;0,0,2,-4)=\ifrac{\kappa}{z^{2}}, w(z;\tfrac{1}{2}(\kappa+\mu)^{2},-\tfrac{1}{2},\tfrac{1}{2}(\mu-1)^{2},\tfrac{ 1}{2}\kappa(2-\kappa))=\dfrac{z}{\kappa+\mu z}, with \kappa and \mu arbitrary constants.

In the general case, \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} has rational solutions if a+b+c+d=2n+1, where n\in\mathbb{Z} , a=\varepsilon_{1}\sqrt{2\alpha} , b=\varepsilon_{2}\sqrt{-2\beta} , c=\varepsilon_{3}\sqrt{2\gamma} , and d=\varepsilon_{4}\sqrt{1-2\delta} , with \varepsilon_{j}=\pm 1 , j=1,2,3,4 , independently, and at least one of a , b , c or d is an integer.
These are special cases of §LABEL:sec:PT.SF.P6.

Elementary nonrational solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} are w(z;\mu,0,0,-\mu\kappa^{3})=\kappa z^{1/3}, w(z;0,-2\kappa,0,4\kappa\mu-\lambda^{2})=z(\kappa(\ln z)^{2}+\lambda\ln z+\mu), w(z;-
u^{2}\lambda,0,
u^{2}(\lambda^{2}-4\kappa\mu),0)=\dfrac{z^{
u-1}}{ \kappa z^{2
u}+\lambda z^{
u}+\mu}, with \kappa , \lambda , \mu , and 
u arbitrary constants.
In the case \gamma=0 and \alpha\delta\neq 0 we assume, as in §LABEL:sec:PT.DE.REN, \alpha=1 and \delta=-1.
Then \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} has algebraic solutions iff \beta=2n, with n\in\mathbb{Z}.

These are rational solutions in \zeta=z^{1/3} of the form w(z)=\ifrac{P_{n^{2}+1}(\zeta)}{Q_{n^{2}}(\zeta)}, where P_{n^{2}+1}(\zeta) and Q_{n^{2}}(\zeta) are polynomials of degrees n^{2}+1 and n^{2} , respectively, with no common zeros.
For examples and plots see ( ) and ( ) .
Similar results hold when \delta=0 and \beta\gamma\neq 0.

\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} with \beta=\delta=0 has a first integral z^{2}(w^{\prime})^{2}+2zww^{\prime}=(C+2\alpha zw+\gamma z^{2}w^{2})w^{2}, with C an arbitrary constant, which is solvable by quadrature.
A similar result holds when \alpha=\gamma=0.
\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} with \alpha=\beta=\gamma=\delta=0 , has the general solution w(z)=Cz^{\mu} , with C and \mu arbitrary constants.

Elementary nonrational solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} are w(z;\mu,-\tfrac{1}{8},-\mu\kappa^{2},0)=1+\kappa z^{1/2}, w(z;0,0,\mu,-\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2})=\kappa\exp\left(\mu z\right), with \kappa and \mu arbitrary constants.

\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} , with \delta=0 , has algebraic solutions if either \mspace{17.0mu }(\alpha,\beta,\gamma)=(\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2},-\tfrac{1}{8}(2n-1) ^{2},-1), or \mspace{5.0mu }(\alpha,\beta,\gamma)=(\tfrac{1}{8}(2n-1)^{2},-\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^ {2},1), with n\in\mathbb{Z} and \mu arbitrary.

These are rational solutions in \zeta=z^{1/2} of the form w(z)=\ifrac{P_{n^{2}-n+1}(\zeta)}{Q_{n^{2}-n}(\zeta)}, where P_{n^{2}-n+1}(\zeta) and Q_{n^{2}-n}(\zeta) are polynomials of degrees n^{2}-n+1 and n^{2}-n , respectively, with no common zeros.
\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} , with \gamma=\delta=0 , has a first integral z^{2}(w^{\prime})^{2}=(w-1)^{2}(2\alpha w^{2}+Cw-2\beta), with C an arbitrary constant, which is solvable by quadrature.
For examples and plots see ( ) .
\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} , with \alpha=\beta=0 and \gamma^{2}+2\delta=0 , has solutions w(z)=C\exp\left(\pm\sqrt{-2\delta}z\right) , with C an arbitrary constant.

An elementary algebraic solution of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} is w(z;\tfrac{1}{2}\kappa^{2},-\tfrac{1}{2}\kappa^{2},\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2},\tfrac{ 1}{2}(1-\mu^{2}))=z^{1/2}, with \kappa and \mu arbitrary constants.
( ) classifies all algebraic solutions for the special case of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} with \beta=\gamma=0 , \delta=\tfrac{1}{2}.
For further examples of algebraic solutions see ( ) , ( ) , ( , §48) , ( ) , ( ) , and ( ) .

For certain combinations of the parameters, \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} – \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} have particular solutions expressible in terms of the solution of a Riccati differential equation, which can be solved in terms of special functions defined in other chapters.

All solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} – \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} that are expressible in terms of special functions satisfy a first-order equation of the form (w^{\prime})^{n}+\sum_{j=0}^{n-1}F_{j}(w,z)(w^{\prime})^{j}=0, where F_{j}(w,z) is polynomial in w with coefficients that are rational functions of z.
\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} has solutions expressible in terms of Airy functions (§LABEL:sec:AI.DE) iff \alpha=n+\tfrac{1}{2}, with n\in\mathbb{Z}.

For example, if \alpha=\tfrac{1}{2}\varepsilon , with \varepsilon=\pm 1 , then the Riccati equation is \varepsilon w^{\prime}=w^{2}+\tfrac{1}{2}z, with solution w(z;\tfrac{1}{2}\varepsilon)=-\varepsilon\phi^{\prime}(z)/\phi(z), where \phi(z)=C_{1}\mathrm{Ai}\left(-2^{-1/3}z\right)+C_{2}\mathrm{Bi}\left(-2^{-1/3 }z\right), with C_{1} , C_{2} arbitrary constants.
Solutions for other values of \alpha are derived from w(z;\pm\tfrac{1}{2}) by application of the Bäcklund transformations (LABEL:eq:PT.BT.P21) and (LABEL:eq:PT.BT.P22).

For example, w(z;\tfrac{3}{2})=\Phi-\dfrac{1}{2\Phi^{2}+z}, w(z;\tfrac{5}{2})=\dfrac{1}{2\Phi^{2}+z}+\dfrac{2z\Phi^{2}+\Phi+z^{2}}{4\Phi^{ 3}+2z\Phi-1}, where \Phi=\phi^{\prime}(z)/\phi(z) , with \phi(z) given by (LABEL:eq:PT.SF.eq23).

More generally, if n=1,2,3,\dots , then w(z;n+\tfrac{1}{2})=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\left(\ln\left(\frac{\tau_{n }(z)}{\tau_{n+1}(z)}\right)\right), where \tau_{n}(z) is the n\times n determinant \tau_{n}(z)=\begin{vmatrix}\phi(z)&\phi^{\prime}(z)&\cdots&\phi^{(n-1)}(z)\\ \phi^{\prime}(z)&\phi^{\prime\prime}(z)&\cdots&\phi^{(n)}(z)\\ \vdots&\vdots&\ddots&\vdots\\ \phi^{(n-1)}(z)&\phi^{(n)}(z)&\cdots&\phi^{(2n-2)}(z)\end{vmatrix}, and w(z;-n-\tfrac{1}{2})=-w(z;n+\tfrac{1}{2}).
If \gamma\delta\neq 0 , then as in §LABEL:sec:PT.DE.REN we may set \gamma=1 and \delta=-1.

\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} then has solutions expressible in terms of Bessel functions (§LABEL:sec:BS.DEF) iff \varepsilon_{1}\alpha+\varepsilon_{2}\beta=4n+2, with n\in\mathbb{Z} , and \varepsilon_{1}=\pm 1 , \varepsilon_{2}=\pm 1 , independently.
In the case \varepsilon_{1}\alpha+\varepsilon_{2}\beta=2 , the Riccati equation is zw^{\prime}=\varepsilon_{1}zw^{2}+(\alpha\varepsilon_{1}-1)w+\varepsilon_{2}z.
For examples and plots see ( ) .
For determinantal representations see ( ) and ( ) .

\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize IV}} has solutions expressible in terms of parabolic cylinder functions (§LABEL:sec:PC.DE) iff either \beta=-2(2n+1+\varepsilon\alpha)^{2}, or \beta=-2n^{2}, with n\in\mathbb{Z} and \varepsilon=\pm 1.

In the case when n=0 in ( LABEL:eq:PT.SF.eq40a), the Riccati equation is w^{\prime}=\varepsilon(w^{2}+2zw)-2(1+\varepsilon\alpha), which has the solution w(z)=-\varepsilon\phi^{\prime}(z)/\phi(z), where \phi(z)=\left(C_{1}U\left(a,\sqrt{2}z\right)+C_{2}V\left(a,\sqrt{2}z\right) \right)\exp\left(\tfrac{1}{2}\varepsilon z^{2}\right), with a=\alpha+\tfrac{1}{2}\varepsilon , and C_{1} , C_{2} arbitrary constants.

When a+\tfrac{1}{2} is zero or a negative integer the U parabolic cylinder functions reduce to Hermite polynomials (§LABEL:sec:OP.CP.OR) times an exponential function; thus w(z;-m,-2(m-1)^{2})=-\frac{H_{m-1}'\left(z\right)}{H_{m-1}\left(z\right)}, subject to m=1,2,3,\dots, and w(z;-m,-2(m+1)^{2})=-2z+\frac{H_{m}'\left(z\right)}{H_{m}\left(z\right)}, subject to m=0,1,2,\dots.

If 1+\varepsilon\alpha=0 , then (LABEL:eq:PT.SF.eq41) has solutions w(z)=\begin{cases}\dfrac{2\exp\left(z^{2}\right)}{\sqrt{\pi}\left(C-i \operatorname{erfc}\left(iz\right)\right)},&\varepsilon=1,\\ \dfrac{2\exp\left(-z^{2}\right)}{\sqrt{\pi}\left(C-\operatorname{erfc}\left(z \right)\right)},&\varepsilon=-1,\end{cases} where C is an arbitrary constant and \operatorname{erfc} is the complementary error function (§ LABEL:sec:ER.DF.ER).
For examples and plots see ( ) .
For determinantal representations see ( ) and ( ) .
If \delta\neq 0 , then as in §LABEL:sec:PT.DE.REN we may set \delta=-\tfrac{1}{2}.

\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} then has solutions expressible in terms of Whittaker functions (§LABEL:sec:CH.KM.DE.WH), iff a+b+\varepsilon_{3}\gamma=2n+1, or (a-n)(b-n)=0, where n\in\mathbb{Z} , a=\varepsilon_{1}\sqrt{2\alpha} , and b=\varepsilon_{2}\sqrt{-2\beta} , with \varepsilon_{j}=\pm 1 , j=1,2,3 , independently.
In the case when n=0 in (LABEL:eq:PT.SF.eq50a), the Riccati equation is zw^{\prime}=aw^{2}+(b-a+\varepsilon_{3}z)w-b.

If a\neq 0 , then (LABEL:eq:PT.SF.eq51) has the solution w(z)=-z\phi^{\prime}(z)/(a\phi(z)), where \phi(z)=\frac{C_{1}M_{\kappa,\mu}\left(\zeta\right)+C_{2}W_{\kappa,\mu}\left( \zeta\right)}{\zeta^{(a-b+1)/2}}\exp\left(\tfrac{1}{2}\zeta\right), with \zeta=\varepsilon_{3}z , \kappa=\tfrac{1}{2}(a-b+1) , \mu=\tfrac{1}{2}(a+b) , and C_{1} , C_{2} arbitrary constants.
For determinantal representations see ( ) , ( ) , and ( ) .

\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} has solutions expressible in terms of hypergeometric functions (§LABEL:sec:HY.GA.GS) iff a+b+c+d=2n+1, where n\in\mathbb{Z} , a=\varepsilon_{1}\sqrt{2\alpha} , b=\varepsilon_{2}\sqrt{-2\beta} , c=\varepsilon_{3}\sqrt{2\gamma} , and d=\varepsilon_{4}\sqrt{1-2\delta} , with \varepsilon_{j}=\pm 1 , j=1,2,3,4 , independently.
If n=1 , then the Riccati equation is w^{\prime}=\frac{aw^{2}}{z(z-1)}+\frac{(b+c)z-a-c}{z(z-1)}w-\frac{b}{z-1}.

If a\neq 0 , then (LABEL:eq:PT.SF.eq61) has the solution w(z)=\frac{\zeta-1}{a\phi(\zeta)}\frac{\mathrm{d}\phi}{\mathrm{d}\zeta}, \zeta=\frac{1}{1-z}, where \phi(\zeta)=C_{1}F\left(b,-a;b+c;\zeta\right)+C_{2}\zeta^{-b+1-c}\*F\left(-a-b -c+1,-c+1;2-b-c;\zeta\right), with C_{1} , C_{2} arbitrary constants.

Next, let \Lambda=\Lambda(u,z) be the elliptic function (§§LABEL:sec:JA.if.c,LABEL:sec:WE.2(iii))defined by u=\int_{0}^{\Lambda}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{t(t-1)(t-z)}}, where the fundamental periods 2\phi_{1} and 2\phi_{2} are linearly independent functions satisfying the hypergeometric equation z(1-z)\frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}\phi}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}+(1-2z)\frac{\mathrm{d} \phi}{\mathrm{d}z}-\tfrac{1}{4}\phi=0.

Then \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} , with \alpha=\beta=\gamma=0 and \delta=\tfrac{1}{2} , has the general solution w(z;0,0,0,\tfrac{1}{2})=\Lambda(C_{1}\phi_{1}+C_{2}\phi_{2},z), with C_{1} , C_{2} arbitrary constants.

The solution (LABEL:eq:PT.DE.PVIc) is an essentially transcendental function of both constants of integration since \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} with \alpha=\beta=\gamma=0 and \delta=\tfrac{1}{2} does not admit an algebraic first integral of the form P(z,w,w^{\prime},C)=0 , with C a constant.
For determinantal representations see ( ) and ( ) .

There are solutions of (LABEL:eq:PT.DE.PI) such that w(x)=-\sqrt{\tfrac{1}{6}|x|}+d|x|^{-1/8}\sin\left(\phi(x)-\theta_{0}\right)+o \left(|x|^{-1/8}\right), subject to x\to-\infty, where \phi(x)=(24)^{1/4}\left(\tfrac{4}{5}|x|^{5/4}-\tfrac{5}{8}d^{2}\ln|x|\right), and d and \theta_{0} are constants.
There are also solutions of (LABEL:eq:PT.DE.PI) such that w(x)\sim\sqrt{\tfrac{1}{6}|x|}, subject to x\to-\infty.
Next, for given initial conditions w(0)=0 and w^{\prime}(0)=k , with k real, w(x) has at least one pole on the real axis.

There are two special values of k , k_{1} and k_{2} , with the properties -0.45142\;8<k_{1}<-0.45142\; 7, 1.85185\;3<k_{2}<1.85185\; 5, and such that: If k<k_{1} , then w(x)>0 for x_{0}<x<0 , where x_{0} is the first pole on the negative real axis.
If k_{1}<k<k_{2} , then w(x) oscillates about, and is asymptotic to, -\sqrt{\tfrac{1}{6}|x|} as x\to-\infty.
If k_{2}<k , then w(x) changes sign once, from positive to negative, as x passes from x_{0} to 0.

Any nontrivial real solution of (LABEL:eq:PT.AAr.P2eq5) that satisfies (LABEL:eq:PT.AAr.P2eq6) is asymptotic to k\mathrm{Ai}\left(x\right) , for some nonzero real k , where \mathrm{Ai} denotes the Airy function (§LABEL:sec:AI.DE).
Conversely, for any nonzero real k , there is a unique solution w_{k}(x) of (LABEL:eq:PT.AAr.P2eq5) that is asymptotic to k\mathrm{Ai}\left(x\right) as x\to+\infty.

If |k|<1 , then w_{k}(x) exists for all sufficiently large |x| as x\to-\infty , and w_{k}(x)=d|x|^{-1/4}\sin\left(\phi(x)-\theta_{0}\right)+o\left(|x|^{-1/4} \right), where \phi(x)=\tfrac{2}{3}|x|^{3/2}-\tfrac{3}{4}d^{2}\ln|x|, and d (\neq 0) , \theta_{0} are real constants.

If |k|>1 , then w_{k}(x) has a pole at a finite point x=c_{0} , dependent on k , and w_{k}(x)\sim\operatorname{sign}\left(k\right)(x-c_{0})^{-1}, subject to x\to c_{0}+.

Replacement of w by iw in (LABEL:eq:PT.AAr.P2eq5) gives w^{\prime\prime}=-2w^{3}+xw.

Any nontrivial real solution of (LABEL:eq:PT.AE.21) satisfies w(x)=d|x|^{-1/4}\sin\left(\phi(x)-\chi\right)+O\left(|x|^{-5/4}\ln|x|\right), subject to x\to-\infty, where \phi(x)=\tfrac{2}{3}|x|^{3/2}+\tfrac{3}{4}d^{2}\ln|x|, with d (\neq 0) and \chi arbitrary real constants.

In the case when \chi+\tfrac{3}{2}d^{2}\ln 2-\tfrac{1}{4}\pi-\operatorname{ph}\Gamma\left( \tfrac{1}{2}id^{2}\right)=n\pi, with n\in\mathbb{Z} , we have w(x)\sim k\mathrm{Ai}\left(x\right), subject to x\to+\infty, where k is a nonzero real constant.

subsection.title: Korteweg–de Vries and Modified Korteweg–de Vries Equations

para.sentence: The modified Korteweg–de Vries (mKdV) equation v_{t}-6v^{2}v_{x}+v_{xxx}=0, has the scaling reduction z=x(3t)^{-1/3}, v(x,t)=(3t)^{-1/3}w(z), where w(z) satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} with \alpha a constant of integration.
The Korteweg–de Vries (KdV) equation u_{t}+6uu_{x}+u_{xxx}=0, has the scaling reduction z=x(3t)^{-1/3}, u(x,t)=-(3t)^{-2/3}(w^{\prime}+w^{2}), where w(z) satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}}.

Equation (LABEL:eq:PT.App.kdv1) also has the similarity reduction z=x+3\lambda t^{2}, u(x,t)=W(z)-\lambda t, where \lambda is an arbitrary constant and W(z) is expressible in terms of solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}}.
See ( ) and P. J. ( , p. 194) .
The sine-Gordon equation u_{xt}=\sin u, has the scaling reduction z=xt, u(x,t)=v(z), where v(z) satisfies (LABEL:eq:PT.DE.cPIII) with \alpha=\tfrac{1}{2} and \gamma=0.
In consequence if w=\exp\left(-iv\right) , then w(z) satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} with \alpha=-\beta=\tfrac{1}{2} and \gamma=\delta=0.
See also ( ) .

The Boussinesq equation u_{tt}=u_{xx}-6(u^{2})_{xx}+u_{xxxx}, has the traveling wave solution z=x-ct, u(x,t)=v(z), where c is an arbitrary constant and v(z) satisfies v^{\prime\prime}=6v^{2}+(c^{2}-1)v+Az+B, with A and B constants of integration.
Depending whether A=0 or A\neq 0 , v(z) is expressible in terms of the Weierstrass elliptic function (§LABEL:sec:WE.2) or solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize I}} , respectively.
Let S_{N} be the group of permutations \boldsymbol{\pi} of the numbers 1,2,\dots,N (§ LABEL:sec:CM.BD).

With 1\leq m_{1}<\cdots<m_{n}\leq N , \boldsymbol{\pi}(m_{1}),\boldsymbol{\pi}(m_{2}),\dots,\boldsymbol{\pi}(m_{n}) is said to be an increasing subsequence of \boldsymbol{\pi} of length n when \boldsymbol{\pi}(m_{1})<\boldsymbol{\pi}(m_{2})<\cdots<\boldsymbol{\pi}(m_{n}).
Let \ell_{N}(\boldsymbol{\pi}) be the length of the longest increasing subsequence of \boldsymbol{\pi}.

Then \lim_{N\to\infty}\mathrm{Prob}\left(\frac{\ell_{N}(\boldsymbol{\pi})-2\sqrt{N} }{N^{1/6}}\leq s\right)=F(s), where the distribution function F(s) is defined here by F(s)=\exp\left(-\int_{s}^{\infty}(x-s)w^{2}(x)\mathrm{d}x\right), and w(x) satisfies \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} with \alpha=0 and boundary conditions w(x)\sim\mathrm{Ai}\left(x\right), subject to x\to+\infty, , w(x)\sim\sqrt{-\tfrac{1}{2}x}, subject to x\to-\infty, where \mathrm{Ai} denotes the Airy function (§LABEL:sec:AI.DE).

The distribution function F(s) given by (LABEL:eq:PT.Com.eq3a)arises in random matrix theory where it gives the limiting distribution for thenormalized largest eigenvalue in the Gaussian Unitary Ensemble of n\times n Hermitian matrices; see ( ) .
See ( ) for other instances of Painlevé equations in random matrix theory.

Let p_{n}(\xi) , n=0,1,\dots , be the orthonormal set of polynomials defined by \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\exp\left(-\tfrac{1}{4}\xi^{4}-z\xi^{2}\right)p_{m}(\xi )p_{n}(\xi)\mathrm{d}\xi=\delta_{m,n}, with recurrence relation a_{n+1}(z)p_{n+1}(\xi)=\xi p_{n}(\xi)-a_{n}(z)p_{n-1}(\xi), for n=1,2,\dots ; compare §LABEL:sec:OP.GE. Then u_{n}(z)=(a_{n}(z))^{2} satisfies the nonlinear recurrence relation (u_{n+1}+u_{n}+u_{n-1})u_{n}=n-2zu_{n}, for n=1,2,\dots , and also \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize IV}} with \alpha=-\tfrac{1}{2}n and \beta=-\tfrac{1}{2}n^{2}.
For this result and applications see ( ) : in this reference, on the right-hand side of Eq. (1.10),
(n+\gamma)^{2} should be replaced by n+\gamma at its first appearance.
